Campaigns

UGC + Affiliate Campaign Playbook for Product Launches

RZ
Rezuan Published Jan 05, 2025
Campaigns

UGC brings authenticity, affiliates bring conversion infrastructure. When you blend the two intentionally, launches feel like community events instead of ads. Here‚Äôs my step-by-step system.

Phase 1: Source and vet creators

I start inside customer communities, Slack groups, and social channels to find people already talking about the product. Vetting includes reviewing their content quality, engagement ratios, and brand safety. Each creator gets a brief questionnaire about their workflow, preferred platforms, and ability to shoot raw assets.

Phase 2: Creative enablement

Selected creators receive an enablement hub built in Notion: brand story, messaging pillars, demo access, legal guidelines, and a CTA library. I record a Loom walkthrough explaining the campaign timeline and show example scripts. The more context creators have, the better they improvise.

Phase 3: Storyboarding each asset

Even ‚Äúauthentic‚Äù content needs structure. I map each video with a hook, tension point, aha moment, and CTA. Hooks might be ‚Äú3 automations I stole from XYZ‚Äù or ‚ÄúWatch me replace five apps with one dashboard.‚Äù I encourage creators to include before/after shots, screen recordings, or audio overlays.

Phase 4: Production sprints

Creators submit drafts to a shared Slack channel. We provide lightweight notes‚Äîfix disclosures, tighten audio, or add captions. Turnaround stays fast because everyone works from the same storyboard.

Phase 5: Landing page + funnel alignment

Every UGC asset gets a dedicated landing page that mirrors the narrative. If a video highlights ‚Äúsaving time on invoices,‚Äù the page hero repeats that promise verbatim. Embedded clips autoplay muted with captions. Below, I include bullet lists summarizing the video, testimonials, and the exact bonus stack available via the affiliate link. Forms capture email + intent so automation can personalize follow-ups.

Phase 6: Lifecycle + retargeting

Leads enter a short nurture series repurposing UGC snippets‚ÄîGIFs, quotes, audio clips. Retargeting ads feature the same creators to maintain continuity. CTAs highlight scarcity (‚ÄúCreator-only onboarding slots close Sunday‚Äù) and link back to the review for added proof.

Phase 7: Tracking + dashboards

Each creator link uses unique UTMs. I monitor performance in Looker Studio: views, clicks, opt-ins, EPC, and revenue. Creators receive weekly scorecards so they know how their content performs. Competition-friendly leaderboards encourage iteration.

Maintenance and iteration

After launch we host a retro call: what content converted best, which hooks flopped, and how bonuses influenced results. Winning scripts become templates for future creators. Underperforming stories go back into research‚Äîwe interview viewers to learn where the narrative broke.

Compensation framework

I offer a hybrid model: flat fee for production, boosted commission on sales generated, and tiered bonuses when milestones are hit (e.g., $1k additional for 100 signups). Creators feel invested in performance because upside exists beyond the initial payment.

Compliance and disclosure

Every asset includes clear audio + visual disclosure (‚ÄúSponsored by Rezuan‚Äôs partner link‚Äù). I provide copy snippets and stylized lower-thirds to maintain consistency. For international campaigns we localize disclosures with native speakers.

Tool stack

  • Notion hub for creative briefs.\n- Slack or Discord for feedback loops.\n- Frame.io or Google Drive for asset delivery.\n- ConvertKit for email nurtures.\n- Looker Studio for dashboards.\n- Zapier to sync performance data into Airtable leaderboards.

Case study: Productivity SaaS

We activated eight creators who built ‚Äúday in the life‚Äù TikToks and YouTube Shorts. Their audiences cared about reducing admin work. Landing pages offered a Notion template + 30-minute onboarding workshop. The campaign drove 4,200 opt-ins, and 18% converted within two weeks. The leaderboard sparked friendly competition‚Äîtop creators earned extra revenue, and the SaaS partner invited them to future beta programs.

Common pitfalls

  1. Random creators ‚Äì Work with actual users or ambassadors; strangers feel forced.\n2. No narrative handoff ‚Äì If landing pages don‚Äôt mirror the video story, conversion drops.\n3. Slow feedback ‚Äì Creators lose momentum if approvals drag.\n4. Missing tracking ‚Äì Without unique links you can‚Äôt reward top performers.\n5. Static bonuses ‚Äì Refresh them so repeat visitors still see something new.

Launch checklist

  • Recruit + vet creators\n- Build Notion enablement hub\n- Storyboard every asset\n- Produce + approve content\n- Launch matching landing pages\n- Configure UTMs + dashboards\n- Run lifecycle and retargeting\n- Host retro + iterate

Sample timeline

  • Week 0: Research creators, secure contracts.\n- Week 1: Build enablement hub and run kickoff call.\n- Week 2: Creators script + shoot drafts.\n- Week 3: Review, edit, and finalize assets.\n- Week 4: Launch landing pages and email nurtures.\n- Week 5: Optimize CTAs, rotate bonuses, and share scorecards.\n- Week 6+: Run refresh sprints for the top-performing creators.

Team roles

  1. Producer ‚Äì manages creators, scripts, and deadlines.\n2. Copy strategist ‚Äì ensures landing pages and emails echo the UGC narrative.\n3. Designer ‚Äì builds visual systems for captions, overlays, and landing pages.\n4. Analyst ‚Äì tracks performance and shares insights.\n5. Partner manager ‚Äì aligns bonuses and handles payouts.\n\nSmall teams can combine roles, but responsibilities must be clear.

Why it works

Creators supply relatable stories, affiliates supply CRO systems. Together they make launches flexible without losing the rigor required for large payouts. Give creators structure, deliver a trustworthy funnel, and both sides win. Keep iterating on the partnership and launches will feel more like collaborations than campaigns.

Final reminder

UGC + affiliate partnerships are living systems. Stay in touch with creators, share performance data transparently, rotate hooks, and celebrate wins publicly. When everyone feels the momentum, they‚Äôll gladly show up for the next launch with even better ideas. Treat the process like an editorial calendar: plan, produce, analyze, and refresh. The more predictable the system, the more creative everyone can be. Your audience will sense the realness‚Äîand convert. Keep shipping, keep inviting, keep iterating. The compounding effect is massive. Creators become true partners, audiences stay loyal. Keep the momentum alive. Keep the drumbeat going. Momentum builds trust. Always be collaborating.
